blog.title: coffee & limes
blog.description:
mom, reader and writer of fanfiction (I'm 40 and give 0 fucks), bi, multi-ethnic, tattooed
check out my side blogs @sebastianincolor and @sebastianinblackandwhite

body:
Double standard

So I was super excited Sandra Oh winning for Killing Eve and moved the show up my queue. Made it to episode 6 and honestly I’ve turned it off. I am disgusted and appalled that Eve put her hands on her husband. Is this supposed to make me think she is stronger or more empowered. I think she is an abuser. I don’t want to see her story or wonder why the scene just cut off and if they’ll address her role as abuser.

My guess is they won’t address it. My guess is they will brush it off as an extension of her personality.

I fully admit I bring my own past as a victim into this. My perception of what abuse is varies from someone who isn’t clinically diagnosed with PTSD from abuse. I get that. But I’m still disappointed in the show and the choices it made.

Killing Eve, along with I, Tonya, will remain unfinished for me. I cannot watch a character put hands on another and not be held accountable.

This was especially hard for me in I, Tonya as I adore Sebastian Stan and when his Jeff smacked Tonya in the truck I had a full blown panic attack. I couldn’t bring myself to go past that, couldn’t watch and wait for the next strike, the next hit, I would have watched that character on scene and stared at the hands and the eyes waiting for the next blow.

I would really like in this day and age of accountability for abuse, physical and emotional abuse, to be treated with much more care. And no it’s still not okay if it’s a woman hitting a man.

tags: if you come into my asks and tell me shakespeare is pretentious i'm gonna cut off the dicks he so liked to joke about
you can ignore this if you wanna
summary: Anna as Olivia, Villanelle as Viola: Parallels Between Killing Eve and Shakespeare’s Twelfth Night
title: Anna as Olivia, Villanelle as Viola: Parallels Between Killing Eve and Shakespeare’s Twelfth Night
body:
I’m reading Shakespeare’s Twelfth Night for a class and in the middle of discussing it these parallels just jumped right out at me, so I’ve decided to write all my thoughts down and post them here for your enjoyment and pondering. So here we go!

–

       Because I’m reading Shakespeare’s Twelfth Night for a class, I’m gonna talk about it, and couldn’t help but notice there were some definite parallels between characters in the play to characters in Killing Eve. More specifically, Anna. (And Villanelle, but she’ll come in a little later.)

           In the play Twelfth Night, the character of Olivia is in mourning. The first glimpse of her we get is not directly from her, but from Orsino’s servant Valentine describing Olivia to him. She’s lost her brother and has been mourning him for “seven summers.” (It’s safe to assume that then means “seven years.”) She’s worn a veil, has sworn she wouldn’t even go outside for those seven years. Lines 27-30 state: “But, like a cloistress, she will veilèd walk/And water once a day her chamber round/With eye-offending brine.” Brine, of course, refers to salt. Salting a memory, her brother, to preserve him.

           If we take this into the context of Killing Eve and Anna, we know that the murder of her husband took place in 2011, the same year Oksana/Villanelle was arrested. The present of the show—most likely—takes place in 2018. Seven years. In episode 8, Villanelle mentions the apartment looks exactly the same, right down to the Cactus Chair. So within those seven years, Anna hasn’t been able to get over the loss of Max. Keeping things as they were—the apartment, the books, the chairs—was her way of preserving the memory of her husband. She tried to find life outside of her loss and mourning, as evidenced in episode 7 when we see her in the massive library, but ultimately, she didn’t move on. A theory that could apply to both Olivia and Anna is their mourning period lasted for that long because it was an effort to stop time, to keep it from moving forward, so that their loss might feel a little less like loss. (It should also be noted that, in Shakespeare’s time, the period of mourning was about a year.)

           Coming back to Twelfth Night again, we’re introduced to Viola, and she and Olivia are in very similar situations. They’ve both lost a brother, but they have very different reactions to it. Viola is able to move forward because there really is no other choice for her; she’s landed on the shore of Illyria and has an appointed task. Therefore, Viola’s relationship to time is different than Olivia’s. To apply this to Villanelle, she is, in a way, like Viola. Someone she loved was lost, though in betrayal—as Villanelle would view it—and though she also mourned the loss in her own way (by writing to Anna from prison, sending her a coat once out), she eventually had to move on and forward because she was chosen by the Twelve, to train to become an assassin. There wasn’t much of a choice but to move on, yet also like Viola, the ghosts are still there.

           This was a terribly long post and a theory and something that just jumped out at me while we discussed this in class, so thank you for sticking with it; now back to our regularly scheduled posting!

summary:
Elena: you fainted, do you remember anything? 
Villanelle: only the ambulance ride to the hospital
Kenny: there was no...
body:
Elena: you fainted, do you remember anything?


Villanelle: only the ambulance ride to the hospital


Kenny: there was no ambulance, I drove you


Villanelle: but I heard sirens


Eve: sorry I got nervous

summary:
Eve: So babe, what do you want to try with me that you have never tried with anyone else?
Villanelle: Emotional intimacy.
body:
Eve: So babe, what do you want to try with me that you have never tried with anyone else?
Villanelle: Emotional intimacy.

summary:
Elena: Why is Villanelle lying on the sidewalk across the street? 
Kenny: She’s a bit overwhelmed
Elena: Why?
Kenny: Eve smiled...
body:
Elena: Why is Villanelle lying on the sidewalk across the street?

Kenny: She’s a bit overwhelmed

Elena: Why?

Kenny: Eve smiled at her from her window

tags: i have so many about this god tier episode
i could probably talk about it for hours
ep 5 is one of the best episodes of television ever created
i wish i could erase it from my mind
so i could watch it for the first time again
summary:
can we please talk about eve’s face during the dinner scene!! 
when villanelle leans in to sniff her neck, it’s so involuntary,...
body:
can we please talk about eve’s face during the dinner scene!!

when villanelle leans in to sniff her neck, it’s so involuntary, but she melts into the movement. like she can’t help but enjoy villanelle being that close to her. it’s so incredibly erotic, she loses the composure she’s been maintaining throughout the scene. she loses herself in the moment. all it would take for her to succumb is one little lean in, just as all it took for that bus stop window to shatter was one little push.

it would be so easy and so tempting and so tantalizing to let villanelle have her right then and there. to ignore her constantly running mind for a mere second. to surrender to what she truly wants, what her body is telling her she wants.

it makes me wonder: if niko and dom hadn’t come through the door, what would have happened?

tags: its just such a heart stopping moment
summary: honestly that scene in killing eve where villanelle is in the club and has just killed you-know and then she makes eye contact...
body: honestly that scene in killing eve where villanelle is in the club and has just killed you-know and then she makes eye contact with eve from across the dance floor and everything is blue and the music is pulsating and time kind of slows down for a second yeah I get chills just thinking about it
